Introduction to Agda

Initial examples of types in Agda

We pronounce suc as â€œsuccessorâ€.

More sophisticated examples of types in Agda

Sometimes we may wish to consider lists over a type A of a given length n : â„•. The elements of this type, written Vector A n, are called vectors, and the type can be defined as follows:

data Vector (A : Type) : â„• â†’ Type where
 []   : Vector A 0
 _::_ : {n : â„•} â†’ A â†’ Vector A n â†’ Vector A (suc n)

This is called a dependent type because it is a type that depends on elements n of another type, namely â„•.

In Agda, we canâ€™t define the head and tail functions on lists, because they are undefined for the empty list, and functions must be total in Agda. Vectors solve this problem:

head : {A : Type} {n : â„•} â†’ Vector A (suc n) â†’ A
head (x :: xs) = x

tail : {A : Type} {n : â„•} â†’ Vector A (suc n) â†’ Vector A n
tail (x :: xs) = xs

Agda accepts the above definitions because it knows that the input vector has at least one element, and hence does have a head and a tail. Here is another example.

Dependent types are pervasive in Agda.

The empty type and the unit type

The identity type former _â‰¡_

The identity type is a little bit subtle and there is a lot to say about it. For the moment, letâ€™s convince ourselves that we can convert back and forth between the types x â‰¡ y and x â‰£ y, in the case that A is the type of natural numbers, as follows:

forth (suc x) (suc y) p = I

Propositions as types

The CurryHoward interpretation of logic, after Haskell Curry and William Howard, interprets logical statements, also known as propositions, as types. Per Martin-LÃ¶f extended this interpretation of propositions as types with equality, by introducing the identity type discussed above.

An incomplete table of the CurryHowardâ€“Martin-LÃ¶f interpretation of logical propositions is the following:

Proposition Type
A implies B function type A â†’ B
âˆ€ x : A, B x dependent function type (x : A) â†’ B x
equality identity type _â‰¡_

This was enough for our examples above.

For more complex examples of reasoning about programs, we need to complete the following table:

Logic English Type
Â¬ A not A ?
A âˆ§ B A and B ?
A âˆ¨ B A or B ?
A â†’ B A implies B A â†’ B
âˆ€ x : A, B x for all x:A, B x (x : A) â†’ B x
âˆƒ x : A, B x there is x:A such that B x ?
x = y x equals y x â‰¡ y

This will be the subject of future handouts.

Remarks

  • (*) Not only the unit type ğŸ™, but also any type with at least one element can be regarded as â€œtrueâ€ in the propositions-as-types interpretation.

  • In Agda we can use any notation we like, of course, and people do use slightly different notatations for e.g.Â ğŸ˜, ğŸ, + and Î£.

  • We will refer to the above type theory together with the type â„• of natural numbers as Basic Martin-LÃ¶f Type Theory.

  • As we will see, this type theory is very expressive and allows us to construct rather sophisticated types, including e.g.Â lists, vectors and trees.

  • All types in MLTT (Martin-LÃ¶f type theory) come with introduction and elimination principles.

The empty type ğŸ˜

It is convenient to have an empty type ğŸ˜, with no elements at all. For example, this can be used in order to define negation, among other things.

data ğŸ˜ : Type where

And thatâ€™s the complete definition. The list of constructors that define the type ğŸ˜ is empty.

Perhaps counter-intuitively, there is one function ğŸ˜ â†’ ğŸ˜, namely the identity function. So although the type ğŸ˜ is empty, the type ğŸ˜ â†’ ğŸ˜ is non-empty. In fact, the non-dependent elimination principle generalizes that.

Proposition as types interpretation

The empty type is used to interpret â€œfalseâ€. Because there is no way to prove the statement false, we use the empty type to represent false as a type.

In logic, in order to prove that a proposition is false, we assume it is true and use this assumption to reach a contradiction, such as 0 = 1. With proofs as programs, in order to show that a statement represented by a type A is false, we assume a hypothetical element x : A, and from this we try to build a (necessarily impossible) element of the type ğŸ˜, which is the desired contradiction. Because of this, in logic the negation of A is defined as A implies false or A implies a contradiction. Hence in type theory we define the negation of a type A to be the function type A â†’ ğŸ˜: 
Â¬_ : Type â†’ Type
Â¬ A = A â†’ ğŸ˜

infix 1000 Â¬_

Elimination principle

ğŸ˜-elim : {A : ğŸ˜ â†’ Type} (x : ğŸ˜) â†’ A x
ğŸ˜-elim ()

The absurd pattern () expresses the fact that there is no pattern available because the type is empty. So in the same way that we define the type by giving an empty list of constructors, we define the function ğŸ˜-elim by giving an empty list of equations. But we indicate this explicitly with the absurd pattern.

In terms of logic, this says that in order to show that a property A of elements of the empty type holds for all x : ğŸ˜, we have to do nothing, because there is no element to check, and by doing nothing we exhaust all possibilities. This is called vacuous truth.

It is important to notice that this is not a mere technicality. Weâ€™ll see practical examples in due course.

The non-dependent version of the eliminator says that there is a function from the empty type to any type: 
ğŸ˜-nondep-elim : {A : Type} â†’ ğŸ˜ â†’ A
ğŸ˜-nondep-elim {A} = ğŸ˜-elim {Î» _ â†’ A}

Definition of emptiness

On the other hand, there is a function f : A â†’ ğŸ˜ if and only if A has no elements, that is, if A is also empty. This is because if x : A, there is no element y : ğŸ˜ we can choose in order to define f x to be y. In fact, we make this observation into our definition of emptiness: 
is-empty : Type â†’ Type
is-empty A = A â†’ ğŸ˜

So notice that this is the same definition as that of negation.

Here is another example of a type that is empty. In the introduction we defined the identity type former _â‰¡_, which we will revisit, and we have that, for example, the type 3 â‰¡ 4 is empty, whereas the type 3 â‰¡ 3 has an element refl 3. Here are some examples coded in Agda:

ğŸ™-is-nonempty f = f â‹†
The last function works as follows. First we unfold the definition of Â¬ is-empty ğŸ™ to get is-empty ğŸ™ â†’ ğŸ˜. Unfolding again, we get the type (ğŸ™ â†’ ğŸ˜) â†’ ğŸ˜. So, given a hypothetical function f : ğŸ™ â†’ ğŸ˜, which of course cannot exist (and this what we are trying to conclude), we need to produce an element of ğŸ˜. We do this by simply applying the mythical f to â‹† : ğŸ™. We can actually incorporate this discussion in the Agda code, if we want:

  Î³ : (ğŸ™ â†’ ğŸ˜) â†’ ğŸ˜

Agda accepts this second version because it automatically unfolds definitions, just as we have done above, to check whether what we have written makes sense. In this case, Agda knows that Â¬ is-empty ğŸ™ is exactly the same thing as (ğŸ™ â†’ ğŸ˜) â†’ ğŸ˜ by definition of Â¬ and is-empty. More examples are given in the file negation.

In logical terms, this says that it order to prove that a property A of elements of the unit type ğŸ™ holds for all elements of the type ğŸ™, it is enough to prove that it holds for the element â‹†. The non-dependent version says that if A holds, then â€œtrue implies Aâ€.

The binary type ğŸš

Notice that the non-dependent version is like if-then-else, if we think of one of the elements of A as true and the other as `false.

The dependent version generalizes the type of the non-dependent version, with the same definition of the function.

Products

We discuss function types of the form A â†’ B (called non-dependent function types) and of the form (x : A) â†’ B x (called dependent function types). The latter are also called products in type theory and this terminology comes from mathematics.

The identity function

To introduce functions, we use Î»-abstractions. For example, the identity function can be defined as follows: 
  id : {A : Type} â†’ A â†’ A
  id = Î» x â†’ x
But of course this function can be equivalently written as follows, which we take as our official definition: 
id : {A : Type} â†’ A â†’ A
id x = x

Logical implication

A logical implication A â†’ B is represented by the function type A â†’ B, and it is a happy coincidence that both use the same notation.

In terms of logic, the identity function implements the tautology â€œA implies Aâ€ when we understand the type A as a logical proposition. In general, most things we define in Agda have a dual interpretation type/proposition or program/proof, like this example.

The elimination principle for function types is given by function application, which is built-in in Agda, but we can explicitly (re)define it. We do with the arguments swapped here: 
modus-ponens : {A B : Type} â†’ A â†’ (A â†’ B) â†’ B
modus-ponens a f = f a

Modus ponens is the rule logic that says that if the proposition A holds and A implies B, then B also holds. The above definition gives a computational realization of this.

Dependent functions

As already discussed, a dependent function type (x : A) â†’ B x, with A : Type and B : A â†’ Type, is that of functions with input x in the type A and output in the type B x. It is called â€œdependentâ€ because the output type B x depends on the input element x : A.

Universal quantification

The logical interpretation of (x : A) â†’ B x is â€œfor all x : A, B xâ€. This is because in order to show that this universal quantification holds, we have to show that B x holds for each given x:A. The input is the given x : A, and the output is a justification of B x. We will see some concrete examples shortly.

Dependent function composition

Composition can be defined for â€œnon-dependent functionsâ€, as in usual mathematics, and, more generally, with dependent functions. With non-dependent functions, it has the following type and definition: 
  _âˆ˜_ : {A B C : Type} â†’ (B â†’ C) â†’ (A â†’ B) â†’ (A â†’ C)
  g âˆ˜ f = Î» x â†’ g (f x)

In terms of computation, this means â€œfirst do f and then do gâ€. For this reason the function composition g âˆ˜ f is often read â€œg after fâ€. In terms of logic, this implements â€œIf B implies C and also A implies B, then A implies Câ€.

With dependent types, it has the following more general type but the same definition, which is the one we adopt:

_âˆ˜_ : {A B : Type} {C : B â†’ Type}
    â†’ ((y : B) â†’ C y)
    â†’ (f : A â†’ B)
    â†’ (x : A) â†’ C (f x)
g âˆ˜ f = Î» x â†’ g (f x)

Its computational interpretation is the same, â€œfirst do f and then do gâ€, but its logical understanding changes: â€œIf it is the case that for all y : B we have that C y holds, and we have a function f : A â†’ B, then it is also the case that for all x : A, we have that C (f x) holdsâ€.

Î  notation

We have mentioned in the propositions as types table that the official notation in MLTT for the dependent function type uses Î , the Greek letter Pi, for product. We can, if we want, introduce the same notation in Agda, using a syntax declaration: 
Pi : (A : Type) (B : A â†’ Type) â†’ Type
Pi A B = (x : A) â†’ B x

syntax Pi A (Î» x â†’ b) = Î  x ê‰ A , b

Important. We are using the alternative symbol ê‰ (typed â€œ\:4â€ in the emacs mode for Agda), which is different from the reserved symbol â€œ:â€. We will use the same alternative symbol when we define syntax for the sum type Î£.

Notice that, for some reason, Agda has this kind of definition backwards. The end result of this is that now (x : A) â†’ B x can be written as Î  x ê‰ A , B x in Agda as in type theory. (If you happen to know a bit of maths, you may be familiar with the cartesian product of a family of sets, and this is the reason the letter Î  is used.)

The sum type former Î£

Very often in computation we work with the type of pairs (x , y) with x : A and y : B where A and B are types. We will write A Ã— B for the type of such pairs, and call it the cartesian product. We will define this type as a particular case of a more general type, whose elements are again of the form (x , y) but with the difference that x : A and y : B x where A : Type and B : A â†’ Type. The difference amounts to the fact that the type of the second component y depends on the first element x. The default notation for this type will be Î£ {A} B, or simply Î£ B when A can be inferred from the context, but we will also introduce the more common sum notation Î£ x ê‰ A , B x. This type is also called the disjoint union of the type family B : A â†’ Type.

Examples

A simple example is the type Î£ xs ê‰ List X , Vector X (length xs) with X : Type. An element of this type is a pair (xs , ys) where xs is a list and ys is a vector of the same length as xs.

Another example, which iterates the Î£ type construction, is Î£ x : â„• , Î£ y : â„• , Î£ z : â„• , x â‰¡ y * z. An element of this type is now a quadruple (x , (y , (z , p))) where x y z : â„• and p : x â‰¡ y * z. That is, the fourth component ensures that x y z : â„• are allowed in the tuple if, and only if, x â‰¡ y * z. We will see more interesting examples shortly.

Definition

The Î£ type can be defined in Agda using a data declaration as follows: 
  data Î£ {A : Type } (B : A â†’ Type) : Type  where
   _,_ : (x : A) (y : B x) â†’ Î£ {A} B

  fst : {A : Type} {B : A â†’ Type} â†’ Î£ B â†’ A
  fst (x , y) = x

  snd : {A : Type} {B : A â†’ Type} â†’ (z : Î£ B) â†’ B (fst z)
  snd (x , y) = y

Notice that the type of snd is dependent and uses fst to express the dependency.

However, for a number of reasons to be explained later, we prefer to define it using a record definition:

record Î£ {A : Type } (B : A â†’ Type) : Type  where
 constructor
  _,_
 field
  fst : A
  snd : B fst

Here we automatically get the projections with the same types and definitions as above and hence we donâ€™t need to provide them. In order for the projections fst and snd to be visible outside the scope of the record, we open the record. Moreover, we open it public so that when other files import this one, these two projections will be visible in the other files. The â€œconstructorâ€ allows to form an element of this type. Because â€œ,â€ is not a reserved symbol in Agda, we can use it as a binary operator to write x , y. However, following mathematical tradition, we will write brackets around that, to get (x , y), even if this is not necessary. We also declare a fixity and precedence for this operator.

open Î£ public
infixr 0 _,_

Because we make _,_ right associative, we can write (x , y , z , p) rather than (x , (y , (z , p))) as we did above.

We also use a syntax declaration, as we did for dependent function types using Î , to get the more traditional type-theoretical notation. 
Sigma : (A : Type) (B : A â†’ Type) â†’ Type
Sigma A B = Î£ {A} B

syntax Sigma A (Î» x â†’ b) = Î£ x ê‰ A , b

infix -1 Sigma

Elimination principle

We now define and discuss the elimination principle. 
Î£-elim : {A : Type } {B : A â†’ Type} {C : (Î£ x ê‰ A , B x) â†’ Type}
       â†’ ((x : A) (y : B x) â†’ C (x , y))
       â†’ (z : Î£ x ê‰ A , B x) â†’ C z
Î£-elim f (x , y) = f x y
So the elimination principle for Î£ is what was called curry in functional programming. The logical interpretation for this principle is that in order to show that â€œfor all z : Î£ x ê‰ A , B x) we have that C z holdsâ€, it is enough to show that â€œfor all x : A and y : B x we have that C (x , y) holdsâ€. This condition is not only sufficient but also necessary: 
Î£-uncurry : {A : Type } {B : A â†’ Type} {C : (Î£ x ê‰ A , B x) â†’ Type}
          â†’ ((z : Î£ x ê‰ A , B x) â†’ C z)
          â†’ (x : A) (y : B x) â†’ C (x , y)
Î£-uncurry g x y = g (x , y)

Existential quantification

Regarding logic, the Î£ type is used to interpret the existential quantifier âˆƒ. The logical proposition âˆƒ x : X, A x, that is, â€œthere exists x : X such that A xâ€, is interpreted as the type Î£ x ê‰ X , A x. The reason is that to show that âˆƒ x : X, A x we have to exhibit an example x : X and show that x satisfies the condition A x with some y : A x, in a pair (x , y).

For example, the type Î£ x : â„• , Î£ y : â„• , Î£ z : â„• , x â‰¡ y * z can be interpreted as saying that â€œthere are natural numbers x, y, and z such that x = y * zâ€, which is true as witnessed by the element (6,2,3,refl 6) of that type. But there are many other witnesses of this type, of course, such as (10,5,2,refl 10).

It is important to notice that it is possible to write types that correspond to false logical statements, and hence are empty. For example, consider Î£ x : â„• , x â‰¡ x + 1. There is no natural number that is its own successor, of course, and so this type is empty. While this type is empty, the type Â¬ (Î£ x : â„• , x â‰¡ x + 1) has an element, as we will see, which witnesses the fact that â€œthere doesnâ€™t exist a natural number x such that x = x + 1.

Existential quantification in HoTT/UF

In HoTT/UF it useful to have an alternative existential quantifier âˆƒ x : X , A x defined to be âˆ¥ Î£ x : X , A x âˆ¥ where âˆ¥_âˆ¥ is a certain propositional truncation operation.

As discussed before, the cartesian product A Ã— B is simply Î£ {A} (Î» x â†’ B) which means that for (x , y) : A Ã— B the type of y is always B, independently of what x is. Using our special syntax for Î£ this can be defined as follows in Agda:

_Ã—_ : Type â†’ Type â†’ Type
A Ã— B = Î£ x ê‰ A , B

infixr 2 _Ã—_

So the elements of A Ã— B are of the form (x , y) with x : A and y : B.

Logical conjunction (â€œandâ€)

The logical interpretation of A Ã— B is â€œA and Bâ€. This is because in order to show that the proposition â€œA and Bâ€ holds, we have to show that each of A and B holds. To show that A holds we exhibit an element x of A, and to show that B holds we exhibit an element y of B, and so to show that â€œA and Bâ€ holds we exhibit a pair (x , y) with x : A and b : B

Logical equivalence

We now can define bi-implication, or logical equivalence, as follows: 
_â‡”_ : Type â†’ Type â†’ Type
A â‡” B = (A â†’ B) Ã— (B â†’ A)

The symbol â‡” is often pronounced â€œif and only ifâ€.

We use the first and second projections to extract the left-to-right implication and the right-to-left implication:

Alternative definition of _Ã—_

This is the same as (or, more precisely, isomorphic to) the Either type defined earlier (you can try this as an exercise). The notation in type theory is _+_, but we want to reserve this for addition of natural numbers, and hence we use the same symbol with a dot on top:

The type A âˆ” B is called the coproduct of A and B, or the sum of A and B, or the disjoint union of A and B. The elements of A âˆ” B are of the form inl x with x : A and inr y with y : B.

In terms of computation, we use the type A âˆ” B when we want to put the two types together into a single type. For example, the unit type ğŸ™ has exactly one element, namely â‹† : ğŸ™, and hence the type ğŸ™ âˆ” ğŸ™ has precisely two elements, namely inl â‹† and inr â‹†.

In terms of logic, we use the type A âˆ” B to express â€œA or Bâ€. This is because in order for â€œA or Bâ€ to hold, at least one of A and B must hold. The type A â†’ A âˆ” B of the function inl is interpreted as saying that if A holds then so does â€œA or Bâ€, and similarly, the type of B â†’ A âˆ” B of the function inr says that if B holds then so does â€œA or Bâ€. In other words, if x : A is a proof of A, then inl x : A + B is a proof of A or B, and if y : B is a proof of B, them inr y : A + B is a proof of â€œA or Bâ€. Here when we said â€œproofâ€ we meant â€œprogramâ€ after the propositions-as-types and proofs-as-programs paradigm.

Logical disjunction in HoTT/UF

In HoTT/UF it useful to have an alternative disjunction operation A âˆ¨ B defined to be âˆ¥ A âˆ” B âˆ¥ where âˆ¥_âˆ¥ is a certain propositional truncation operation.

Elimination principle

Now suppose we want to define a dependent function (z : A âˆ” B) â†’ C z. How can we do that? If we have two functions f : (x : A) â†’ C (inl x) and g : (y : B) â†’ C (inr y), then, given z : A âˆ” B, we can inspect whether z is of the form inl x with x : A or of the form inr y with y : B, and the respectively apply f or g to get an element of C z. This procedure is called the elimination principle for the type former _âˆ”_ and can be written in Agda as follows:

âˆ”-elim : {A B : Type} (C : A âˆ” B â†’ Type)
       â†’ ((x : A) â†’ C (inl x))
       â†’ ((y : B) â†’ C (inr y))
       â†’ (z : A âˆ” B) â†’ C z
âˆ”-elim C f g (inl x) = f x
âˆ”-elim C f g (inr y) = g y
So the eliminator amounts to simply definition by cases. In terms of logic, it says that in order to show that â€œfor all z : A âˆ” B we have that C z holdsâ€ it is enough to show two things: (1) â€œfor all x : A it is the case that C (inl x) holdsâ€, and (2) â€œforall y : B it is the case that C (inr y) holdsâ€. This is not only sufficient, but also necessary: 
open import binary-products

âˆ”-split : {A B : Type} (C : A âˆ” B â†’ Type)
        â†’ ((z : A âˆ” B) â†’ C z)
        â†’ ((x : A) â†’ C (inl x)) Ã— ((y : B) â†’ C (inr y))
âˆ”-split {A} {B} C h = f , g
 where
  f : (x : A) â†’ C (inl x)
  f x = h (inl x)

  g : (y : B) â†’ C (inr y)
  g y = h (inr y)
There is also a version of the eliminator in which C doesnâ€™t depend on z : A âˆ” B and is always the same: 
âˆ”-nondep-elim : {A B C : Type}
              â†’ (A â†’ C)
              â†’ (B â†’ C)
              â†’ (A âˆ” B â†’ C)
âˆ”-nondep-elim {A} {B} {C} = âˆ”-elim (Î» z â†’ C)
In terms of logic, this means that in order to show that â€œA or B implies Câ€, it is enough to show that both â€œA implies Câ€ and â€œB implies Câ€. This also can be inverted: 
âˆ”-nondep-split : {A B C : Type}
               â†’ (A âˆ” B â†’ C)
               â†’ (A â†’ C) Ã— (B â†’ C)
âˆ”-nondep-split {A} {B} {C} = âˆ”-split (Î» z â†’ C)

In terms of logic, this means that if A or B implies C then both A implies C and B implies C.

The identity type former _â‰¡_

The original and main terminology for the following type is identity type, but sometimes it is also called the equality type. Sometimes this is also called propositional equality, but we will avoid this terminology as it sometimes leads to confusion.

Elimination principle

The elimination principle for this type, also called J in the literature, is defined as follows: 
â‰¡-elim : {X : Type} (A : (x y : X) â†’ x â‰¡ y â†’ Type)
       â†’ ((x : X) â†’ A x x (refl x))
       â†’ (x y : X) (p : x â‰¡ y) â†’ A x y p
â‰¡-elim A f x x (refl x) = f x

This says that in order to show that A x y p holds for all x y : X and p : x â‰¡ y, it is enough to show that A x x (refl x) holds for all x : X. In the literature, this elimination principle is called J. Again, we are not going to use it explicitly, because we can use definitions by pattern matching on refl, just as we did for defining it.

We also have the non-dependent version of the eliminator: 
â‰¡-nondep-elim : {X : Type} (A : X â†’ X â†’ Type)
              â†’ ((x : X) â†’ A x x)
              â†’ (x y : X) â†’ x â‰¡ y â†’ A x y
â‰¡-nondep-elim A = â‰¡-elim (Î» x y _ â†’ A x y)

A property of two variables like A above is referred to as a relation. The assumption (x : X) â†’ A x x says that the relation is reflexive. Then the non-dependent version of the principle says that the reflexive relation given by the identity type _â‰¡_ can always be mapped to any reflexive relation, or we may say that _â‰¡_ is the smallest reflexive relation on the type X.

The type â„• of natural numbers

Elimination principle

The elimination principle for all type formers follow the same pattern: they tell us how to define dependent functions out of the given type. In the case of natural numbers, the eliminator gives primitive recursion. Given a base case a : A 0 and a step function f : (k : â„•) â†’ A k â†’ A (suc k), we get a function h : (n : â„•) â†’ A n defined by primitive recursion as follows: 
â„•-elim : {A : â„• â†’ Type}
       â†’ A 0
       â†’ ((k : â„•) â†’ A k â†’ A (suc k))
       â†’ (n : â„•) â†’ A n
â„•-elim {A} a f = h
 where
  h : (n : â„•) â†’ A n
  h 0       = a
  h (suc n) = f n (h n)
In usual accounts of primitive recursion outside type theory, one encounters the following particular case of primitive recursion, which is the non-dependent version of the above. 
â„•-nondep-elim : {A : Type}
              â†’ A
              â†’ (â„• â†’ A â†’ A)
              â†’ â„• â†’ A
â„•-nondep-elim {A} = â„•-elim {Î» _ â†’ A}
Notice that this is like fold for lists, if you know about this. There is a further restricted version, which is usually called iteration: 
â„•-iteration : {A : Type}
            â†’ A
            â†’ (A â†’ A)
            â†’ â„• â†’ A
â„•-iteration a f = â„•-nondep-elim a (Î» k x â†’ f x)

Intuitively, â„•-iteration a f n = f (f (f (â‹¯ f a))) where we apply n times the function f to the element a, which sometimes is written fâ¿(a) in the literature.

The induction principle for â„•

In logical terms, one can see immediately what the type of â„•-elim is: it is simply the principle of induction on natural numbers, which say that in order to show that a property A holds for all natural numbers, it is enough to show that A 0 holds (this is called the base case), and that if A k holds then so does A (suc k) (this is called the induction step). In Agda, in practice, we donâ€™t explicitly use this induction principle, but instead write definition recursively, just as we defined the above function h recursively.

Function extensionality

Recall that we defined pointwise equality f âˆ¼ g of functions in the identity type handout. The principle of function extensionality says that pointwise equal functions are equal and is given by the following type FunExt:

Unfortunately, this principle is not provable or disprovable in Agda or MLTT (we say that it is independent). But it is provable in Cubical Agda, which is based on Cubical Type Theory and is outside the scope of these lecture notes. Sometimes we will use function extensionality as an explicit assumption.

Propositions as types versus propositions as booleans

When programming in conventional programming languages such as Haskell, C, Java, Python, etc., we use booleans rather than types to encode logical propositions. But this works only because we restrict ourselves to decidable propositions, as weâ€™ll see below.

We now discuss why we use types to encode logical propositions, and when we can use booleans instead. It is not always.

Discussion and motivation

Examples. We can automatically check equality of booleans, integers, strings and much more, using algorithms.

Counter-example. We canâ€™t check equality of functions of type â„• â†’ â„•, for instance. Intuitively, to check that two functions f and g of this type are equal, we need to check infinitely many cases, namely f x = g x for all x : â„•. But, we are afraid, intuition is not enough. This has to be proved. Luckily in our case, Alan Turing provided the basis to prove that. He showed that the Halting Problem canâ€™t be solved by an algorithm in any programming language. It follows from this that we canâ€™t check whether two such functions f and g are equal or not using an algorithm.

The above examples and counter-examples show that sometimes we can decide equality with an algorithm, and sometimes we canâ€™t. However, for example, the identity type _â‰¡_ applies to all types, whether they have decidable equality or not, and this is why it is useful. We can think about equality, not only in our heads but also in Agda, without worrying whether it can be checked to be true or not by a computer. The identity type is not about checking equality. It is about asserting that two things are equal, and then proving this ourselves. In fact, equality is very often not checkable by the computer. It is instead about stating and proving or disproving equalities, where the proving and disproving is done by people (the lecturers and the students in this case), by hard, intelligent work.

Decidable propositions

Motivated by the above discussion, we define when a logical proposition is decidable under the understanding of propositions as types: 
is-decidable : Type â†’ Type
is-decidable A = A âˆ” Â¬ A

This means that we can produce an element of A or show that no such element can be found.

Although it is not possible in general to write a program of type Â¬Â¬ A â†’ A, this is possible when A is decidable: 
Â¬Â¬-elim : {A : Type} â†’ is-decidable A â†’ Â¬Â¬ A â†’ A
Â¬Â¬-elim (inl x) f = x
Â¬Â¬-elim (inr g) f = ğŸ˜-elim (f g)

Decidable propositions as booleans

The following shows that a type A is decidable if and only if there is b : Bool such that A holds if and only if the boolean b is true.

For the purposes of this handout, understanding the following proof is not important at a first reading. What is important is to understand what the type of the following function is saying, which is what we explained above. 
decidability-with-booleans : (A : Type) â†’ is-decidable A â‡” Î£ b ê‰ Bool , (A â‡” b â‰¡ true)
decidability-with-booleans A = f , g

Decidable predicates as boolean-valued functions

Consider the logical statement â€œx is evenâ€. This is decidable, because there is an easy algorithm that tells whether a natural number x is even or not. In programming languages we write this algorithm as a procedure that returns a boolean. But an equally valid definition is to say that x is even if there is a natural number y such that x = 2 * y. This definition doesnâ€™t automatically give an algorithm to check whether or not x is odd. 
  is-even : â„• â†’ Type
  is-even x = Î£ y ê‰ â„• , x â‰¡ 2 * y
This says what to be even means. But it doesnâ€™t say how we check with a computer program whether a number is even or not, which would be given by a function check-even : â„• â†’ Bool. 
  check-even : â„• â†’ Bool
  check-even 0       = true
  check-even (suc x) = not (check-even x)

For this function to be correct, it has to be the case that

is-even x â‡” check-even x â‰¡ true

Exercise. We believe you have learned enough Agda, try this.

This is possible because

(x : X) â†’ is-decidable (is-even x).

The following generalizes the above discussion and implements it in Agda.

First we define what it means for a predicate, such as A = is-even, to be decidable: 
is-decidable-predicate : {X : Type} â†’ (X â†’ Type) â†’ Type
is-decidable-predicate {X} A = (x : X) â†’ is-decidable (A x)

In our example, this means that we can tell whether a number is even or not.

Next we show that a predicate A is decidable if and only if there is a boolean valued function Î± such that A x holds if and only if Î± x â‰¡ true. In the above example, A plays the role of is-even and alpha plays the role of check-even.

Although boolean-valued predicates are fine, we prefer to use type-valued predicates for the sake of uniformity, because we can always define type valued predicates, but only on special circumstances can we define boolean-valued predicates. It is better to define all predicates in the same way, and then write Agda code for predicates that happen to be decidable.

Preservation of decidability

If A and B are logically equivalent, then A is decidable if and only if B is decidable. We first prove one direction.

Exhaustively searchable types

We will explain in a future lecture why we need to use Typeâ‚ rather than Type in the following definition. For the moment we just mention that because the definition mentions Type, there would be a circularity if the type of the definition where again Type. Such circular definitions are not allowed because if they were then we would be able to prove that 0=1. We have that Type : Typeâ‚ (the type of Type is Typeâ‚) but we canâ€™t have Type : Type.

Type isomorphisms

A function f : A â†’ B is called a bijection if there is a function g : B â†’ A in the opposite direction such that g âˆ˜ f âˆ¼ id and f âˆ˜ g âˆ¼ id. Recall that _âˆ¼_ is pointwise equality and that id is the identity function. This means that we can convert back and forth between the types A and B landing at the same element with started with, either from A or from B. In this case, we say that the types A and B are isomorphic, and we write A â‰… B. Bijections are also called type isomorphisms. We can define these concepts in Agda using sum types or records. We will adopt the latter, but we include both definitions for the sake of illustration. Recall that we defined the domain of a function f : A â†’ B to be A and its codomain to be B.

Here we apply the proposition-as-types interpretation of logic to define the concepts: 
  is-bijection : {A B : Type} â†’ (A â†’ B) â†’ Type
  is-bijection f = Î£ g ê‰ (codomain f â†’ domain f) , ((g âˆ˜ f âˆ¼ id) Ã— (f âˆ˜ g âˆ¼ id))

  _â‰…_ : Type â†’ Type â†’ Type
  A â‰… B = Î£ f ê‰ (A â†’ B) , is-bijection f
And here we give an equivalent definition which uses records and is usually more convenient in practice and is the one we adopt: 
record is-bijection {A B : Type} (f : A â†’ B) : Type where
 constructor
  Inverse
 field
  inverse : B â†’ A
  Î·       : inverse âˆ˜ f âˆ¼ id
  Îµ       : f âˆ˜ inverse âˆ¼ id

record _â‰…_ (A B : Type) : Type where
 constructor
  Isomorphism
 field
  bijection   : A â†’ B
  bijectivity : is-bijection bijection

infix 0 _â‰…_

The definition with Î£ is probably more intuitive, but, as discussed above, the definition with a record is often easier to work with, because we can easily extract the components of the definitions using the names of the fields. It also often allows Agda to infer more types, and to give us more sensible goals in the interactive development of Agda programs and proofs.

Notice that inverse plays the role of g. The reason we use inverse is that then we can use the word inverse to extract the inverse of a bijection. Similarly we use bijection for f, as we can use the word bijection to extract the bijection from a record.

Some basic examples

  fg ğŸ = refl ğŸ

Notice that the above argument, in Agda, not only shows that the types are indeed isomorphic, but also explains how and why they are isomorphic. Thus, logical arguments coded in Agda are useful not only to get confidence in correctness, but also to gain understanding.

The booleans

We discuss the elimination principle for the booleans. The booleans are defined by constructors true and false: 
data Bool : Type where
 true false : Bool

if-then-else

The non-dependent eliminator of the type of booleans amounts to if-then-else 
if_then_else_ : {A : Type} â†’ Bool â†’ A â†’ A â†’ A
if true  then x else y = x
if false then x else y = y

In general, the non-dependent elimination principle of a type explains how to â€œget out of the typeâ€, whereas the constructors tell us how to â€œget into the typeâ€.

Dependent if-then-else

Notice that both x (the then branch) and y (the else branch) have the same type, name A. Using dependent type, we can have different types in the dependent version of the eliminator. We make the type A depend on the boolean condition of the if-then-else. This means that now we will have A : Bool â†’ Type instead of A : Bool. This is a function that given a boolean b : Bool, returns a type A b. Functions whose return value is a type are also called type families. Also A b is called a dependent type. It depends on the value of the boolean b. Here is an example, which we make private to this module. 
private
 open import natural-numbers-type
 A-example : Bool â†’ Type
 A-example true  = â„•
 A-example false = Bool
Using this idea, we have the following dependently-typed version of if_then_else_, which now has four explicit arguments. We make A explicit this time, because Agda can hardly ever infer it. 
dependent-on_if_then_else_ : (A : Bool â†’ Type) â†’ (b : Bool) â†’ A true â†’ A false â†’ A b
dependent-on A if true  then x else y = x
dependent-on A if false then x else y = y
Notice that the return type A b depends on the second argument b of the function. Notice also that x : A true and y : A false. 
private
 exampleâ‚€ : (b : Bool) â†’ A-example b
 exampleâ‚€ b = dependent-on A-example if b then 3 else true

This works because 3 : A-example true and true : A-example false. So the dependent version of if-then-else allows the then and else branches have different types, which depend on the type of the condition.

The official definition of the eliminator of the type of booleans

Traditionally the argument of the type we want to eliminate (the booleans in our case) is written last: 
Bool-elim : (A : Bool â†’ Type)
          â†’ A true
          â†’ A false
          â†’ (b : Bool) â†’ A b
Bool-elim A x y true  = x
Bool-elim A x y false = y

The type of Bool-elim says that if we provide elements of the type A true and A false, we get a function (b : Bool) â†’ A b.

The non-dependent version is a particular case of the dependent version, by considering the constant type family Î» _ â†’ A for a given A : Type. This time we make the first argument A implicit: 
Bool-nondep-elim : {A : Type}
                 â†’ A
                 â†’ A
                 â†’ Bool â†’ A
Bool-nondep-elim {A} = Bool-elim (Î» _ â†’ A)

This produces a function Bool â†’ A from two given elements of the type A.

Logical reading of the eliminator

The conclusion of Bool-elim is (b : Bool) â†’ A b, which under propositions as types has the logical reading â€œfor all b : Bool, the proposition A b holdsâ€. The hypotheses A true and A false are all is needed to reach this conclusion.

Thus the logical reading of Bool-elim is:

  • In order to prove that â€œfor all b : Bool, the proposition A b holdsâ€

it is enough to prove that

  • the proposition A true holds, and

  • the proposition A false holds,

which should be intuitively clear.

Examples of proofs using the eliminator

First define 
not : Bool â†’ Bool
not true  = false
not false = true
Then we can prove that not can be expressed using if-then-else: 
open import identity-type
not-defined-with-if : (b : Bool) â†’ not b â‰¡ if b then false else true
not-defined-with-if true  = refl false
not-defined-with-if false = refl true
Using the eliminator, this can be proved as follows: 
not-defined-with-ifâ‚€ : (b : Bool) â†’ not b â‰¡ if b then false else true
not-defined-with-ifâ‚€ = Bool-elim A x y
 where
  A : Bool â†’ Type
  A b = not b â‰¡ if b then false else true

  x : A true
  x = refl false

  y : A false
  y = refl true
Of course, we can â€œin-lineâ€ the definitions of the where clause: 
not-defined-with-ifâ‚ : (b : Bool) â†’ not b â‰¡ if b then false else true
not-defined-with-ifâ‚ = Bool-elim
                        (Î» b â†’ not b â‰¡ if b then false else true)
                        (refl false)
                        (refl true)
This is shorter but probably less readable. The following is even shorter, using the fact that Agda can infer the property A : Bool â†’ Type we want to prove automatically. We use _ to tell Agda â€œplease figure out yourself what this argument in the function has to beâ€: 
not-defined-with-ifâ‚‚ : (b : Bool) â†’ not b â‰¡ if b then false else true
not-defined-with-ifâ‚‚ = Bool-elim _ (refl false) (refl true)
In situations where we try to use _ but Agda canâ€™t determine that there is a unique answer to what _ should be, the colour yellow is used to indicate this in the syntax highlighting, accompanied by an error message. To give another example, we first define the notion of an involution, or involutive function: 
is-involution : {X : Type} â†’ (X â†’ X) â†’ Type
is-involution {X} f = (x : X) â†’ f (f x) â‰¡ x
For example, list reversal is an involution. Another example is boolean negation: 
not-is-involution : is-involution not
not-is-involution = Bool-elim _ (refl true) (refl false)
A proof without mentioning is-involution and without using the eliminator is also possible, of course: 
not-is-involution' : (b : Bool) â†’ not (not b) â‰¡ b
not-is-involution' true  = refl true
not-is-involution' false = refl false

Very often we will give definitions by pattern-matching as above instead of Bool-elim. But the concept of eliminator for a type remains useful, and it is what MLTT (Martin-LÃ¶f Type Theory), the foundation of our programming language Agda, uses to define types. Types are defined by formation rules, construtors, eliminators, and equations explaining how the constructors interact with the eliminators. Pattern-matching can be considered as â€œsyntax sugarâ€ for definitions using eliminators. Usually definitions using pattern matching are more readable than definitions using eliminators, but they are equivalent to definitions using eliminators.

Notice that in the definition of is-involution we needed to explicitly indicate the implicit argument X using curly brackets. Agda allows the notation âˆ€ in order to be able to omit the type X, provided it can be inferred automaticaly, which it can in our situation: 
is-involution' : {X : Type} â†’ (X â†’ X) â†’ Type
is-involution' f = âˆ€ x â†’ f (f x) â‰¡ x

Some useful functions

true  && y = y
false && y = false

_||_ : Bool â†’ Bool â†’ Bool
true  || y = true
false || y = y

infixr 20 _||_

The booleans

The booleans are isomorphic to a Basic MLTT type:

open import isomorphisms

Bool-isomorphism : Bool â‰… ğŸ™ âˆ” ğŸ™
Bool-isomorphism = record { bijection = f ; bijectivity = f-is-bijection }
 where
  f : Bool â†’ ğŸ™ âˆ” ğŸ™
  f false = inl â‹†
  f true  = inr â‹†

  g : ğŸ™ âˆ” ğŸ™ â†’ Bool
  g (inl â‹†) = false
  g (inr â‹†) = true

  gf : g âˆ˜ f âˆ¼ id
  gf true  = refl true
  gf false = refl false

  fg : f âˆ˜ g âˆ¼ id
  fg (inl â‹†) = refl (inl â‹†)
  fg (inr â‹†) = refl (inr â‹†)

  f-is-bijection : is-bijection f
  f-is-bijection = record { inverse = g ; Î· = gf ; Îµ = fg }

Finite types

We now define a type Fin n which has exactly n elements, where n : â„• is a natural number.

open import natural-numbers-type public

data Fin : â„• â†’ Type where
 zero : {n : â„•} â†’ Fin (suc n)
 suc  : {n : â„•} â†’ Fin n â†’ Fin (suc n)
Examples: 
private

 xâ‚€ = zero
 xâ‚ = suc zero
 xâ‚‚ = suc (suc zero)

 yâ‚€ yâ‚ yâ‚‚ : Fin 3
 yâ‚€ = zero {2}
 yâ‚ = suc {2} (zero {1})
 yâ‚‚ = suc {2} (suc {1} (zero {0}))
And these are all the elements of Fin 3. Notice that Fin 0 is empty:

Fin-0-is-empty ()
Here () is a pseudo-pattern that tells that there is no constructor for the type. 
Fin-suc-is-nonempty : {n : â„•} â†’ Â¬ is-empty (Fin (suc n))
Fin-suc-is-nonempty f = f zero

Elimination principle

Fin-elim : (A : {n : â„•} â†’ Fin n â†’ Type)
         â†’ ({n : â„•} â†’ A {suc n} zero)
         â†’ ({n : â„•} (k : Fin n) â†’ A k â†’ A (suc k))
         â†’ {n : â„•} (k : Fin n) â†’ A k
Fin-elim A a f = h
 where
  h : {n : â„•} (k : Fin n) â†’ A k
  h zero    = a
  h (suc k) = f k (h k)

So this again looks like primitive recursion. And it gives an induction principle for Fin.

Every element of Fin n can be regarded as an element of â„•

Î¹ : {n : â„•} â†’ Fin n â†’ â„•
Î¹ zero    = zero
Î¹ (suc x) = suc (Î¹ x)

Isomorphism of Fin n with a Basic MLTT type

    IH : g n (f n k) â‰¡ k

Lists

This type has already been briefly discussed in the introduction. 
data List (A : Type) : Type where

infixr 10 _::_

Elimination principle

List-elim : {X : Type} (A : List X â†’ Type)
          â†’ A []
          â†’ ((x : X) (xs : List X) â†’ A xs â†’ A (x :: xs))
          â†’ (xs : List X) â†’ A xs
List-elim {X} A a f = h
 where
  h : (xs : List X) â†’ A xs
  h []        = a
  h (x :: xs) = f x xs (h xs)
Notice that the definition of h is the same as that of the usual fold function for lists, but the type is more general. In fact, the fold function is just the non-dependent version of the eliminator 
List-nondep-elim : {X A : Type}
                 â†’ A
                 â†’ (X â†’ List X â†’ A â†’ A)
                 â†’ List X â†’ A
List-nondep-elim {X} {A} a f = List-elim {X} (Î» _ â†’ A) a f

Induction on lists

In terms of logic, the elimination principle gives an induction principle for proving properties of lists.

Order relation â‰¤

Multiplication distributes over addition:

   (x :: xs) ++ [] â‰¡âŸ¨ refl _ âŸ©

   x :: xs         âˆ

List reversal

First an obvious, but slow reversal algorithm: 
reverse : {A : Type} â†’ List A â†’ List A
reverse []        = []
reverse (x :: xs) = reverse xs ++ [ x ]
This is quadratic time. To get a linear-time algorithm, we use the following auxiliary function: 
rev-append : {A : Type} â†’ List A â†’ List A â†’ List A
rev-append []        ys = ys
rev-append (x :: xs) ys = rev-append xs (x :: ys)
The intended behaviour of rev-append is that rev-append xs ys = reverse xs ++ ys. Using this fact, the linear time algorithm is the following: 
rev : {A : Type} â†’ List A â†’ List A
rev xs = rev-append xs []
We now want to show that rev and reverse behave in the same way. To do this, we first show that the auxiliary function does behave as intended: 
rev-append-behaviour : {A : Type} (xs ys : List A)
                     â†’ rev-append xs ys â‰¡ reverse xs ++ ys
rev-append-behaviour []        ys = refl ys
rev-append-behaviour (x :: xs) ys =
   rev-append (x :: xs) ys     â‰¡âŸ¨ refl _ âŸ©
   rev-append xs (x :: ys)     â‰¡âŸ¨ rev-append-behaviour xs (x :: ys) âŸ©
   reverse xs ++ (x :: ys)     â‰¡âŸ¨ refl _ âŸ©
   reverse xs ++ ([ x ] ++ ys) â‰¡âŸ¨ sym (++-assoc (reverse xs) [ x ] ys) âŸ©
   (reverse xs ++ [ x ]) ++ ys â‰¡âŸ¨ refl _ âŸ©
   reverse (x :: xs) ++ ys     âˆ
We state this as follows in Agda: 
rev-correct : {A : Type} (xs : List A) â†’ rev xs â‰¡ reverse xs
rev-correct xs =
   rev xs           â‰¡âŸ¨ refl _ âŸ©
   rev-append xs [] â‰¡âŸ¨ rev-append-behaviour xs [] âŸ©
   reverse xs ++ [] â‰¡âŸ¨ []-right-neutral (reverse xs) âŸ©
   reverse xs       âˆ

The empty type ğŸ˜

It is convenient to have an empty type ğŸ˜, with no elements at all. For example, this can be used in order to define negation, among other things.

data ğŸ˜ : Type where

And thatâ€™s the complete definition. The list of constructors that define the type ğŸ˜ is empty.

Perhaps counter-intuitively, there is one function ğŸ˜ â†’ ğŸ˜, namely the identity function. So although the type ğŸ˜ is empty, the type ğŸ˜ â†’ ğŸ˜ is non-empty. In fact, the non-dependent elimination principle generalizes that.

Proposition as types interpretation

The empty type is used to interpret â€œfalseâ€. Because there is no way to prove the statement false, we use the empty type to represent false as a type.

In logic, in order to prove that a proposition is false, we assume it is true and use this assumption to reach a contradiction, such as 0 = 1. With proofs as programs, in order to show that a statement represented by a type A is false, we assume a hypothetical element x : A, and from this we try to build a (necessarily impossible) element of the type ğŸ˜, which is the desired contradiction. Because of this, in logic the negation of A is defined as A implies false or A implies a contradiction. Hence in type theory we define the negation of a type A to be the function type A â†’ ğŸ˜: 
Â¬_ : Type â†’ Type
Â¬ A = A â†’ ğŸ˜

infix 1000 Â¬_

Elimination principle

ğŸ˜-elim : {A : ğŸ˜ â†’ Type} (x : ğŸ˜) â†’ A x
ğŸ˜-elim ()

The absurd pattern () expresses the fact that there is no pattern available because the type is empty. So in the same way that we define the type by giving an empty list of constructors, we define the function ğŸ˜-elim by giving an empty list of equations. But we indicate this explicitly with the absurd pattern.

In terms of logic, this says that in order to show that a property A of elements of the empty type holds for all x : ğŸ˜, we have to do nothing, because there is no element to check, and by doing nothing we exhaust all possibilities. This is called vacuous truth.

It is important to notice that this is not a mere technicality. Weâ€™ll see practical examples in due course.

The non-dependent version of the eliminator says that there is a function from the empty type to any type: 
ğŸ˜-nondep-elim : {A : Type} â†’ ğŸ˜ â†’ A
ğŸ˜-nondep-elim {A} = ğŸ˜-elim {Î» _ â†’ A}

Definition of emptiness

On the other hand, there is a function f : A â†’ ğŸ˜ if and only if A has no elements, that is, if A is also empty. This is because if x : A, there is no element y : ğŸ˜ we can choose in order to define f x to be y. In fact, we make this observation into our definition of emptiness: 
is-empty : Type â†’ Type
is-empty A = A â†’ ğŸ˜

So notice that this is the same definition as that of negation.

Here is another example of a type that is empty. In the introduction we defined the identity type former _â‰¡_, which we will revisit, and we have that, for example, the type 3 â‰¡ 4 is empty, whereas the type 3 â‰¡ 3 has an element refl 3. Here are some examples coded in Agda: 
ğŸ˜-is-empty : is-empty ğŸ˜
ğŸ˜-is-empty = ğŸ˜-nondep-elim

open import unit-type

ğŸ™-is-nonempty : Â¬ is-empty ğŸ™
ğŸ™-is-nonempty f = f â‹†
The last function works as follows. First we unfold the definition of Â¬ is-empty ğŸ™ to get is-empty ğŸ™ â†’ ğŸ˜. Unfolding again, we get the type (ğŸ™ â†’ ğŸ˜) â†’ ğŸ˜. So, given a hypothetical function f : ğŸ™ â†’ ğŸ˜, which of course cannot exist (and this what we are trying to conclude), we need to produce an element of ğŸ˜. We do this by simply applying the mythical f to â‹† : ğŸ™. We can actually incorporate this discussion in the Agda code, if we want: 
ğŸ™-is-nonempty' : Â¬ is-empty ğŸ™
ğŸ™-is-nonempty' = Î³
 where
  Î³ : (ğŸ™ â†’ ğŸ˜) â†’ ğŸ˜
  Î³ f = f â‹†

Agda accepts this second version because it automatically unfolds definitions, just as we have done above, to check whether what we have written makes sense. In this case, Agda knows that Â¬ is-empty ğŸ™ is exactly the same thing as (ğŸ™ â†’ ğŸ˜) â†’ ğŸ˜ by definition of Â¬ and is-empty. More examples are given in the file negation.

Reasoning with negation

Recall that we defined the negation Â¬ A of a type A to be the function type A â†’ 0, and that we also wrote is-empty A as a synonym of Â¬ A.

Emptiness of the empty type
We have the following two proofs of â€œnot falseâ€ or â€œthe empty type is emptyâ€: 
not-false : Â¬ ğŸ˜
not-false = ğŸ˜-elim

not-false' : Â¬ ğŸ˜
not-false' = id

A lot of things about negation donâ€™t depend on the fact that the target type of the function type is ğŸ˜. We will begin by proving some things about negation by generalizing ğŸ˜ to any type R of â€œresultsâ€.

Implication from disjunction and negation
If Â¬ A or B, then A implies B: 
implication-from-disjunction-and-negation : {A B : Type} â†’ Â¬ A âˆ” B â†’ (A â†’ B)
implication-from-disjunction-and-negation (inl f) a = ğŸ˜-elim (f a)
implication-from-disjunction-and-negation (inr b) a = b
Contrapositives
If A implies B, then B â†’ R implies A â†’ R: 
arrow-contravariance : {A B R : Type}
                     â†’ (A â†’ B)
                     â†’ (B â†’ R) â†’ (A â†’ R)
arrow-contravariance f g = g âˆ˜ f
A particular case of interest is the following. The contrapositive of an implication A â†’ B is the implication Â¬ B â†’ Â¬ A: 
contrapositive : {A B : Type} â†’ (A â†’ B) â†’ (Â¬ B â†’ Â¬ A)
contrapositive {A} {B} = arrow-contravariance {A} {B} {ğŸ˜}

This can also be read as â€œif we have a function A â†’ B and B is empty, then also A must be emptyâ€.

Double and triple negations

We now introduce notation for double and triple negation, to reduce the number of needed brackets:

Â¬Â¬_ Â¬Â¬Â¬_ : Type â†’ Type
Â¬Â¬  A = Â¬(Â¬ A)
Â¬Â¬Â¬ A = Â¬(Â¬Â¬ A)
We have that A implies Â¬Â¬ A. This is called double negation introduction. More generally, we have the following: 
dni : (A R : Type) â†’ A â†’ ((A â†’ R) â†’ R)
dni A R a u = u a

Propositions as types versus propositions as booleans

When programming in conventional programming languages such as Haskell, C, Java, Python, etc., we use booleans rather than types to encode logical propositions. But this works only because we restrict ourselves to decidable propositions, as weâ€™ll see below.

We now discuss why we use types to encode logical propositions, and when we can use booleans instead. It is not always.

Discussion and motivation

Examples. We can automatically check equality of booleans, integers, strings and much more, using algorithms.

Counter-example. We canâ€™t check equality of functions of type â„• â†’ â„•, for instance. Intuitively, to check that two functions f and g of this type are equal, we need to check infinitely many cases, namely f x = g x for all x : â„•. But, we are afraid, intuition is not enough. This has to be proved. Luckily in our case, Alan Turing provided the basis to prove that. He showed that the Halting Problem canâ€™t be solved by an algorithm in any programming language. It follows from this that we canâ€™t check whether two such functions f and g are equal or not using an algorithm.

The above examples and counter-examples show that sometimes we can decide equality with an algorithm, and sometimes we canâ€™t. However, for example, the identity type _â‰¡_ applies to all types, whether they have decidable equality or not, and this is why it is useful. We can think about equality, not only in our heads but also in Agda, without worrying whether it can be checked to be true or not by a computer. The identity type is not about checking equality. It is about asserting that two things are equal, and then proving this ourselves. In fact, equality is very often not checkable by the computer. It is instead about stating and proving or disproving equalities, where the proving and disproving is done by people (the lecturers and the students in this case), by hard, intelligent work.

Decidable propositions
Motivated by the above discussion, we define when a logical proposition is decidable under the understanding of propositions as types: 
is-decidable : Type â†’ Type
is-decidable A = A âˆ” Â¬ A

This means that we can produce an element of A or show that no such element can be found.

Although it is not possible in general to write a program of type Â¬Â¬ A â†’ A, this is possible when A is decidable: 
Â¬Â¬-elim : {A : Type} â†’ is-decidable A â†’ Â¬Â¬ A â†’ A
Â¬Â¬-elim (inl x) f = x
Â¬Â¬-elim (inr g) f = ğŸ˜-elim (f g)
Decidable propositions as booleans

The following shows that a type A is decidable if and only if there is b : Bool such that A holds if and only if the boolean b is true.

For the purposes of this handout, understanding the following proof is not important at a first reading. What is important is to understand what the type of the following function is saying, which is what we explained above.

Decidable predicates as boolean-valued functions
Consider the logical statement â€œx is evenâ€. This is decidable, because there is an easy algorithm that tells whether a natural number x is even or not. In programming languages we write this algorithm as a procedure that returns a boolean. But an equally valid definition is to say that x is even if there is a natural number y such that x = 2 * y. This definition doesnâ€™t automatically give an algorithm to check whether or not x is odd. 
  is-even : â„• â†’ Type
  is-even x = Î£ y ê‰ â„• , x â‰¡ 2 * y
This says what to be even means. But it doesnâ€™t say how we check with a computer program whether a number is even or not, which would be given by a function check-even : â„• â†’ Bool. 
  check-even : â„• â†’ Bool
  check-even 0       = true
  check-even (suc x) = not (check-even x)

For this function to be correct, it has to be the case that

This is possible because

The following generalizes the above discussion and implements it in Agda.

Although boolean-valued predicates are fine, we prefer to use type-valued predicates for the sake of uniformity, because we can always define type valued predicates, but only on special circumstances can we define boolean-valued predicates. It is better to define all predicates in the same way, and then write Agda code for predicates that happen to be decidable.

Preservation of decidability
If A and B are logically equivalent, then A is decidable if and only if B is decidable. We first prove one direction.

Exhaustively searchable types
We will explain in a future lecture why we need to use Typeâ‚ rather than Type in the following definition. Decidable equality

A particular case of interest regarding the above discussion is the notion of a type having decidable equality, which can be written in Agda as follows.

The identity type former _â‰¡_
The original and main terminology for the following type is identity type, but sometimes it is also called the equality type. Sometimes this is also called propositional equality, but we will avoid this terminology as it sometimes leads to confusion. 
data _â‰¡_ {A : Type} : A â†’ A â†’ Type where
 refl : (x : A) â†’ x â‰¡ x

infix 0 _â‰¡_
Elimination principle
The elimination principle for this type, also called J in the literature, is defined as follows: 
â‰¡-elim : {X : Type} (A : (x y : X) â†’ x â‰¡ y â†’ Type)
       â†’ ((x : X) â†’ A x x (refl x))
       â†’ (x y : X) (p : x â‰¡ y) â†’ A x y p
â‰¡-elim A f x x (refl x) = f x

This says that in order to show that A x y p holds for all x y : X and p : x â‰¡ y, it is enough to show that A x x (refl x) holds for all x : X. In the literature, this elimination principle is called J. Again, we are not going to use it explicitly, because we can use definitions by pattern matching on refl, just as we did for defining it.

We also have the non-dependent version of the eliminator: 
â‰¡-nondep-elim : {X : Type} (A : X â†’ X â†’ Type)
              â†’ ((x : X) â†’ A x x)
              â†’ (x y : X) â†’ x â‰¡ y â†’ A x y
â‰¡-nondep-elim A = â‰¡-elim (Î» x y _ â†’ A x y)

A property of two variables like A above is referred to as a relation. The assumption (x : X) â†’ A x x says that the relation is reflexive. Then the non-dependent version of the principle says that the reflexive relation given by the identity type _â‰¡_ can always be mapped to any reflexive relation, or we may say that _â‰¡_ is the smallest reflexive relation on the type X.

Fundamental constructions with the identity type
As an exercise, you may try to rewrite the following definitions to use â‰¡-nondep-elim instead of pattern matching on refl: 
trans : {A : Type} {x y z : A} â†’ x â‰¡ y â†’ y â‰¡ z â†’ x â‰¡ z
trans p (refl y) = p

sym : {A : Type} {x y : A} â†’ x â‰¡ y â†’ y â‰¡ x
sym (refl x) = refl x

ap : {A B : Type} (f : A â†’ B) {x y : A} â†’ x â‰¡ y â†’ f x â‰¡ f y
ap f (refl x) = refl (f x)

apâ‚‚ : {A B C : Type} (f : A â†’ B â†’ C) {x x' : A} {y y' : B}
    â†’ x â‰¡ x' â†’ y â‰¡ y' â†’ f x y â‰¡ f x' y'
apâ‚‚ f (refl x) (refl y) = refl (f x y)

transport : {X : Type} (A : X â†’ Type)
          â†’ {x y : X} â†’ x â‰¡ y â†’ A x â†’ A y
transport A (refl x) a = a

We have already seen the first three. In the literature, ap is often called cong. In logical terms, the last one, often called subst in the literature, says that if x is equal y and A x holds, then so does A y. That is, we can substitute equals for equals in logical statements.

HoTT/UF notation

Pointwise equality of functions
It is often convenient to work with pointwise equality of functions, defined as follows: 
_âˆ¼_ : {A : Type} {B : A â†’ Type} â†’ ((x : A) â†’ B x) â†’ ((x : A) â†’ B x) â†’ Type
f âˆ¼ g = âˆ€ x â†’ f x â‰¡ g x

infix 0 _âˆ¼_

Unfortunately, it is not provable or disprovable in Agda that pointwise equal functions are equal, that is, that f âˆ¼ g implies f â‰¡ g (but it is provable in Cubical Agda, which is outside the scope of these lecture notes). This principle is very useful and is called function extensionality.

Function extensionality
Recall that we defined pointwise equality f âˆ¼ g of functions in the identity type handout. The principle of function extensionality says that pointwise equal functions are equal and is given by the following type FunExt: 
open import identity-type

FunExt = {A : Type} {B : A â†’ Type} {f g : (x : A) â†’ B x} â†’ f âˆ¼ g â†’ f â‰¡ g

Unfortunately, this principle is not provable or disprovable in Agda or MLTT (we say that it is independent). But it is provable in Cubical Agda, which is based on Cubical Type Theory and is outside the scope of these lecture notes. Sometimes we will use function extensionality as an explicit assumption.

Products

We discuss function types of the form A â†’ B (called non-dependent function types) and of the form (x : A) â†’ B x (called dependent function types). The latter are also called products in type theory and this terminology comes from mathematics.

The identity function
To introduce functions, we use Î»-abstractions. For example, the identity function can be defined as follows: 
  id : {A : Type} â†’ A â†’ A
  id = Î» x â†’ x
But of course this function can be equivalently written as follows, which we take as our official definition: 
id : {A : Type} â†’ A â†’ A
id x = x
Logical implication

A logical implication A â†’ B is represented by the function type A â†’ B, and it is a happy coincidence that both use the same notation.

In terms of logic, the identity function implements the tautology â€œA implies Aâ€ when we understand the type A as a logical proposition. In general, most things we define in Agda have a dual interpretation type/proposition or program/proof, like this example.

The elimination principle for function types is given by function application, which is built-in in Agda, but we can explicitly (re)define it. We do with the arguments swapped here: 
modus-ponens : {A B : Type} â†’ A â†’ (A â†’ B) â†’ B
modus-ponens a f = f a

Modus ponens is the rule logic that says that if the proposition A holds and A implies B, then B also holds. The above definition gives a computational realization of this.

Dependent functions

As already discussed, a dependent function type (x : A) â†’ B x, with A : Type and B : A â†’ Type, is that of functions with input x in the type A and output in the type B x. It is called â€œdependentâ€ because the output type B x depends on the input element x : A.

Universal quantification

The logical interpretation of (x : A) â†’ B x is â€œfor all x : A, B xâ€. This is because in order to show that this universal quantification holds, we have to show that B x holds for each given x:A. The input is the given x : A, and the output is a justification of B x. We will see some concrete examples shortly.

Dependent function composition
Composition can be defined for â€œnon-dependent functionsâ€, as in usual mathematics, and, more generally, with dependent functions. With non-dependent functions, it has the following type and definition: 
  _âˆ˜_ : {A B C : Type} â†’ (B â†’ C) â†’ (A â†’ B) â†’ (A â†’ C)
  g âˆ˜ f = Î» x â†’ g (f x)

In terms of computation, this means â€œfirst do f and then do gâ€. For this reason the function composition g âˆ˜ f is often read â€œg after fâ€. In terms of logic, this implements â€œIf B implies C and also A implies B, then A implies Câ€.

With dependent types, it has the following more general type but the same definition, which is the one we adopt:

_âˆ˜_ : {A B : Type} {C : B â†’ Type}
    â†’ ((y : B) â†’ C y)
    â†’ (f : A â†’ B)
    â†’ (x : A) â†’ C (f x)
g âˆ˜ f = Î» x â†’ g (f x)

Its computational interpretation is the same, â€œfirst do f and then do gâ€, but its logical understanding changes: â€œIf it is the case that for all y : B we have that C y holds, and we have a function f : A â†’ B, then it is also the case that for all x : A, we have that C (f x) holdsâ€.

Î  notation
We have mentioned in the propositions as types table that the official notation in MLTT for the dependent function type uses Î , the Greek letter Pi, for product. We can, if we want, introduce the same notation in Agda, using a syntax declaration: 
Pi : (A : Type) (B : A â†’ Type) â†’ Type
Pi A B = (x : A) â†’ B x

syntax Pi A (Î» x â†’ b) = Î  x ê‰ A , b

Important. We are using the alternative symbol ê‰ (typed â€œ\:4â€ in the emacs mode for Agda), which is different from the reserved symbol â€œ:â€. We will use the same alternative symbol when we define syntax for the sum type Î£.

Notice that, for some reason, Agda has this kind of definition backwards. The end result of this is that now (x : A) â†’ B x can be written as Î  x ê‰ A , B x in Agda as in type theory. (If you happen to know a bit of maths, you may be familiar with the cartesian product of a family of sets, and this is the reason the letter Î  is used.)

Propositions as types

The CurryHoward interpretation of logic, after Haskell Curry and William Howard, interprets logical statements, also known as propositions, as types. Per Martin-LÃ¶f extended this interpretation of propositions as types with equality, by introducing the identity type discussed above.

An incomplete table of the CurryHowardâ€“Martin-LÃ¶f interpretation of logical propositions is the following:

âˆ€ x : A, B x dependent function type (x : A) â†’ B x
equality identity type _â‰¡_

This was enough for our examples above.

Â¬ A not A ?
A âˆ§ B A and B ?
A âˆ¨ B A or B ?
A â†’ B A implies B A â†’ B
âˆ€ x : A, B x for all x:A, B x (x : A) â†’ B x
âˆƒ x : A, B x there is x:A such that B x ?
x = y x equals y x â‰¡ y

This will be the subject of future handouts.

The cartesian-product type former _Ã—_

As discussed before, the cartesian product A Ã— B is simply Î£ {A} (Î» x â†’ B) which means that for (x , y) : A Ã— B the type of y is always B, independently of what x is. Using our special syntax for Î£ this can be defined as follows in Agda:

So the elements of A Ã— B are of the form (x , y) with x : A and y : B.

Logical conjunction (â€œandâ€)

The logical interpretation of A Ã— B is â€œA and Bâ€. This is because in order to show that the proposition â€œA and Bâ€ holds, we have to show that each of A and B holds. To show that A holds we exhibit an element x of A, and to show that B holds we exhibit an element y of B, and so to show that â€œA and Bâ€ holds we exhibit a pair (x , y) with x : A and b : B

Logical equivalence

We now can define bi-implication, or logical equivalence, as follows:

The symbol â‡” is often pronounced â€œif and only ifâ€.

Alternative definition of _Ã—_

There is another way to define binary products as a special case of Î  rather than Î£.

The sum type former Î£

Very often in computation we work with the type of pairs (x , y) with x : A and y : B where A and B are types. We will write A Ã— B for the type of such pairs, and call it the cartesian product. We will define this type as a particular case of a more general type, whose elements are again of the form (x , y) but with the difference that x : A and y : B x where A : Type and B : A â†’ Type. The difference amounts to the fact that the type of the second component y depends on the first element x. The default notation for this type will be Î£ {A} B, or simply Î£ B when A can be inferred from the context, but we will also introduce the more common sum notation Î£ x ê‰ A , B x. This type is also called the disjoint union of the type family B : A â†’ Type.

Examples

A simple example is the type Î£ xs ê‰ List X , Vector X (length xs) with X : Type. An element of this type is a pair (xs , ys) where xs is a list and ys is a vector of the same length as xs.

Another example, which iterates the Î£ type construction, is Î£ x : â„• , Î£ y : â„• , Î£ z : â„• , x â‰¡ y * z. An element of this type is now a quadruple (x , (y , (z , p))) where x y z : â„• and p : x â‰¡ y * z. That is, the fourth component ensures that x y z : â„• are allowed in the tuple if, and only if, x â‰¡ y * z. We will see more interesting examples shortly.

Definition
The Î£ type can be defined in Agda using a data declaration as follows: 
  data Î£ {A : Type } (B : A â†’ Type) : Type  where
   _,_ : (x : A) (y : B x) â†’ Î£ {A} B

  fst : {A : Type} {B : A â†’ Type} â†’ Î£ B â†’ A
  fst (x , y) = x

  snd : {A : Type} {B : A â†’ Type} â†’ (z : Î£ B) â†’ B (fst z)

Notice that the type of snd is dependent and uses fst to express the dependency.

However, for a number of reasons to be explained later, we prefer to define it using a record definition:

  _,_

Here we automatically get the projections with the same types and definitions as above and hence we donâ€™t need to provide them. In order for the projections fst and snd to be visible outside the scope of the record, we open the record. Moreover, we open it public so that when other files import this one, these two projections will be visible in the other files. The â€œconstructorâ€ allows to form an element of this type. Because â€œ,â€ is not a reserved symbol in Agda, we can use it as a binary operator to write x , y. Elimination principle
We now define and discuss the elimination principle. 
Î£-elim : {A : Type } {B : A â†’ Type} {C : (Î£ x ê‰ A , B x) â†’ Type}
       â†’ ((x : A) (y : B x) â†’ C (x , y))
       â†’ (z : Î£ x ê‰ A , B x) â†’ C z
Î£-elim f (x , y) = f x y
So the elimination principle for Î£ is what was called curry in functional programming. The logical interpretation for this principle is that in order to show that â€œfor all z : Î£ x ê‰ A , B x) we have that C z holdsâ€, it is enough to show that â€œfor all x : A and y : B x we have that C (x , y) holdsâ€. This condition is not only sufficient but also necessary: 
Î£-uncurry : {A : Type } {B : A â†’ Type} {C : (Î£ x ê‰ A , B x) â†’ Type}
          â†’ ((z : Î£ x ê‰ A , B x) â†’ C z)
          â†’ (x : A) (y : B x) â†’ C (x , y)
Î£-uncurry g x y = g (x , y)
Existential quantification

Regarding logic, the Î£ type is used to interpret the existential quantifier âˆƒ. The logical proposition âˆƒ x : X, A x, that is, â€œthere exists x : X such that A xâ€, is interpreted as the type Î£ x ê‰ X , A x. The reason is that to show that âˆƒ x : X, A x we have to exhibit an example x : X and show that x satisfies the condition A x with some y : A x, in a pair (x , y).

For example, the type Î£ x : â„• , Î£ y : â„• , Î£ z : â„• , x â‰¡ y * z can be interpreted as saying that â€œthere are natural numbers x, y, and z such that x = y * zâ€, which is true as witnessed by the element (6,2,3,refl 6) of that type. But there are many other witnesses of this type, of course, such as (10,5,2,refl 10).

It is important to notice that it is possible to write types that correspond to false logical statements, and hence are empty. For example, consider Î£ x : â„• , x â‰¡ x + 1. There is no natural number that is its own successor, of course, and so this type is empty. While this type is empty, the type Â¬ (Î£ x : â„• , x â‰¡ x + 1) has an element, as we will see, which witnesses the fact that â€œthere doesnâ€™t exist a natural number x such that x = x + 1.

infixr 20 _âˆ”_

The type A âˆ” B is called the coproduct of A and B, or the sum of A and B, or the disjoint union of A and B. The elements of A âˆ” B are of the form inl x with x : A and inr y with y : B.

In terms of computation, we use the type A âˆ” B when we want to put the two types together into a single type. It is also possible to write A âˆ” A, in which case we will have two copies of the type A, so that now every element x of A has two different incarnations inl a and inr a in the type A âˆ” A. For example, the unit type ğŸ™ has exactly one element, namely â‹† : ğŸ™, and hence the type ğŸ™ âˆ” ğŸ™ has precisely two elements, namely inl â‹† and inr â‹†.

Logical disjunction (â€œorâ€)

In terms of logic, we use the type A âˆ” B to express â€œA or Bâ€. This is because in order for â€œA or Bâ€ to hold, at least one of A and B must hold. The type A â†’ A âˆ” B of the function inl is interpreted as saying that if A holds then so does â€œA or Bâ€, and similarly, the type of B â†’ A âˆ” B of the function inr says that if B holds then so does â€œA or Bâ€. In other words, if x : A is a proof of A, then inl x : A + B is a proof of A or B, and if y : B is a proof of B, them inr y : A + B is a proof of â€œA or Bâ€. Here when we said â€œproofâ€ we meant â€œprogramâ€ after the propositions-as-types and proofs-as-programs paradigm.

Logical disjunction in HoTT/UF

In HoTT/UF it useful to have an alternative disjunction operation A âˆ¨ B defined to be âˆ¥ A âˆ” B âˆ¥ where âˆ¥_âˆ¥ is a certain propositional truncation operation.

Elimination principle

Now suppose we want to define a dependent function (z : A âˆ” B) â†’ C z. How can we do that? If we have two functions f : (x : A) â†’ C (inl x) and g : (y : B) â†’ C (inr y), then, given z : A âˆ” B, we can inspect whether z is of the form inl x with x : A or of the form inr y with y : B, and the respectively apply f or g to get an element of C z. This procedure is called the elimination principle for the type former _âˆ”_ and can be written in Agda as follows:

âˆ”-elim : {A B : Type} (C : A âˆ” B â†’ Type)
       â†’ ((x : A) â†’ C (inl x))
       â†’ ((y : B) â†’ C (inr y))
       â†’ (z : A âˆ” B) â†’ C z
âˆ”-elim C f g (inl x) = f x
âˆ”-elim C f g (inr y) = g y
So the eliminator amounts to simply definition by cases. In terms of logic, it says that in order to show that â€œfor all z : A âˆ” B we have that C z holdsâ€ it is enough to show two things: (1) â€œfor all x : A it is the case that C (inl x) holdsâ€, and (2) â€œforall y : B it is the case that C (inr y) holdsâ€. This is not only sufficient, but also necessary: 
open import binary-products

âˆ”-split : {A B : Type} (C : A âˆ” B â†’ Type)
        â†’ ((z : A âˆ” B) â†’ C z)
        â†’ ((x : A) â†’ C (inl x)) Ã— ((y : B) â†’ C (inr y))
âˆ”-split {A} {B} C h = f , g
 where
  f : (x : A) â†’ C (inl x)
  f x = h (inl x)

  g : (y : B) â†’ C (inr y)
  g y = h (inr y)
There is also a version of the eliminator in which C doesnâ€™t depend on z : A âˆ” B and is always the same: 
âˆ”-nondep-elim : {A B C : Type}
              â†’ (A â†’ C)
              â†’ (B â†’ C)
              â†’ (A âˆ” B â†’ C)
âˆ”-nondep-elim {A} {B} {C} = âˆ”-elim (Î» z â†’ C)
In terms of logic, this means that in order to show that â€œA or B implies Câ€, it is enough to show that both â€œA implies Câ€ and â€œB implies Câ€. This also can be inverted: 
âˆ”-nondep-split : {A B C : Type}
               â†’ (A âˆ” B â†’ C)
               â†’ (A â†’ C) Ã— (B â†’ C)
âˆ”-nondep-split {A} {B} {C} = âˆ”-split (Î» z â†’ C)

In terms of logic, this means that if A or B implies C then both A implies C and B implies C.

Alternative definition of _âˆ”_

Type isomorphisms

A function f : A â†’ B is called a bijection if there is a function g : B â†’ A in the opposite direction such that g âˆ˜ f âˆ¼ id and f âˆ˜ g âˆ¼ id. Recall that _âˆ¼_ is pointwise equality and that id is the identity function. This means that we can convert back and forth between the types A and B landing at the same element with started with, either from A or from B. In this case, we say that the types A and B are isomorphic, and we write A â‰… B. Bijections are also called type isomorphisms. We can define these concepts in Agda using sum types or records. We will adopt the latter, but we include both definitions for the sake of illustration. Recall that we defined the domain of a function f : A â†’ B to be A and its codomain to be B.

Here we apply the proposition-as-types interpretation of logic to define the concepts: 
  is-bijection : {A B : Type} â†’ (A â†’ B) â†’ Type
  is-bijection f = Î£ g ê‰ (codomain f â†’ domain f) , ((g âˆ˜ f âˆ¼ id) Ã— (f âˆ˜ g âˆ¼ id))

  _â‰…_ : Type â†’ Type â†’ Type
  A â‰… B = Î£ f ê‰ (A â†’ B) , is-bijection f
And here we give an equivalent definition which uses records and is usually more convenient in practice and is the one we adopt: 
record is-bijection {A B : Type} (f : A â†’ B) : Type where
 constructor
  Inverse
 field
  inverse : B â†’ A
  Î·       : inverse âˆ˜ f âˆ¼ id
  Îµ       : f âˆ˜ inverse âˆ¼ id

record _â‰…_ (A B : Type) : Type where
 constructor
  Isomorphism
 field
  bijection   : A â†’ B
  bijectivity : is-bijection bijection

infix 0 _â‰…_

The definition with Î£ is probably more intuitive, but, as discussed above, the definition with a record is often easier to work with, because we can easily extract the components of the definitions using the names of the fields. It also often allows Agda to infer more types, and to give us more sensible goals in the interactive development of Agda programs and proofs.

Notice that inverse plays the role of g. The reason we use inverse is that then we can use the word inverse to extract the inverse of a bijection. Similarly we use bijection for f, as we can use the word bijection to extract the bijection from a record.

Some basic examples

open import binary-type
open import Bool

Bool-ğŸš-isomorphism : Bool â‰… ğŸš

 where
  f : Bool â†’ ğŸš
  f false = ğŸ
  f true  = ğŸ

  g : ğŸš â†’ Bool
  g ğŸ = false
  g ğŸ = true

  gf : g âˆ˜ f âˆ¼ id
  gf true  = refl true
  gf false = refl false

  fg : f âˆ˜ g âˆ¼ id
  fg ğŸ = refl ğŸ
  fg ğŸ = refl ğŸ

  f-is-bijection : is-bijection f
  f-is-bijection = record { inverse = g ; Î· = gf ; Îµ = fg }
But there is also a different isomorphism:

  g ğŸ = false
